item.title: Decoding JPMorganâ€™s â€˜U.S. Security Indexâ€™: Outlook, Opportunities, and Risks Across 39 Companies
item.content:encoded:
Growing U.S.â€“China strategic rivalry, the global energy transition, and supplyâ€‘chain reconfiguration have pushed several nationalâ€‘securityâ€‘critical industries into the spotlight. A recently floated â€œU.S. Security Indexâ€ â€” attributed in Chinese coverage to Morgan Stanley (â€œDaâ€‘Moâ€) â€” curates 39 listed companies across four segments: nuclear power and uranium, batteries and energy storage, rare earths and strategic metals, and lithium. These companies span energy security, criticalâ€‘mineral supply chains, and defense technology, and are seen as a microcosm of efforts to strengthen U.S. resource and technology selfâ€‘reliance. This report systematically analyzes the four segments in terms of industry context, nationalâ€‘strategy role, supplyâ€“demand dynamics, and outlook, and â€” against the macro and policy backdrop â€” discusses opportunities and risks from an investment perspective.

Nuclear & Uranium: The Foundation of Energy Security

Section titled â€œNuclear & Uranium: The Foundation of Energy Securityâ€

Industry context and strategic role. Nuclear power, a clean baseload source, accounts for roughly 20% of U.S. electricity. Uranium â€” fuel for nuclear reactors and nuclear weapons â€” is strategically vital for both energy and defense. Yet U.S. uranium supply has long relied on imports: in 2023, 99% of enriched uranium used by U.S. reactors was imported, with only 0.05 million pounds produced domestically. A decade of low prices left U.S. uranium mining nearly dormant, creating heavy dependence on overseas supply (notably Russia and Kazakhstan). In a geopolitical crunch, that is a strategic vulnerability. In 2024, the U.S. legislated a ban on imports of Russian enriched uranium (effective August 2024, with limited waivers through 2028) to reduce reliance on â€œunreliable suppliers.â€ As the Senate Energy Committee noted, the U.S. currently lacks a complete nuclearâ€‘fuel production capability, and overâ€‘reliance on Russian supply threatens energy security.

Supplyâ€“demand and outlook. Nuclear is seeing a global revival, with newâ€‘build commitments lifting uranium demand. After years of surplus, supplyâ€“demand has tightened and prices have rebounded. Washington has moved to rebuild the fuel cycle: the Department of Energy (DOE) received $2.7B to restart domestic conversion and enrichment; a strategic uranium reserve was formed to purchase from U.S. miners. Beyond conventional PWR fleets, advanced designs such as small modular reactors (SMRs) are rising and could further expand uranium needs. DOE has contracted for highâ€‘assay lowâ€‘enriched uranium (HALEU) and is backing centrifuge capacity at firms like Centrus Energy (LEU). Domestic output is recovering: U.S. Q3â€‘2024 uranium production reached 120,000 lbs, up 24% q/q. Over time, mine restarts and new projects should reduce import dependence. Near term, however, the U.S. still consumes ~32M lbs per year; backfilling Russian supply amid bans and geopolitical risk is a challenge (increased imports from allies such as Canada/Australia plus faster domestic ramp should help).

Representative companies & investment take. Constituents reportedly include Energy Fuels (UUUU), Cameco (CCJ), and NexGen Energy (NXE). They benefit from higher uranium prices and U.S. policy tailwinds. Cameco â€” a global leader with alliedâ€‘market access â€” is a relatively defensive core holding. U.S. miners such as Energy Fuels are restarting capacity and branching into rareâ€‘earth processing, offering higher growth optionality. Key risks: uraniumâ€™s cyclicality and policy sensitivity. The structural push for fuelâ€‘cycle autonomy supports the mediumâ€‘toâ€‘longâ€‘term case, but shortâ€‘term setbacks (nuclear build pace, macro slowdowns) can hit prices; many junior miners are preâ€‘profit with fragile cash flow, magnifying volatility. Consider focusing on producers with contracts/backlog (e.g., Cameco) and treating explorationâ€‘heavy names with caution and tight sizing.

Batteries & Energy Storage: The Engine of the Transition

Section titled â€œBatteries & Energy Storage: The Engine of the Transitionâ€

Industry context and strategic role. Batteries sit at the core of EVs and renewables. Global EV sales keep setting records â€” >20M expected in 2025, roughly a quarter of auto sales â€” driving exponential battery demand. Gridâ€‘scale storage is surging to firm intermittent wind and solar. Todayâ€™s industry is led by China, Korea, and Japan, with China dominant in capacity and key processes. The U.S., recognizing vulnerability in this supply chain, elevated batteries to a strategic priority: the 2022 Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) offers rich tax credits, catalyzing U.S. manufacturing across cells and materials. As a result, announced U.S. capacity could reach ~1.2 TWh by 2030, up ~70% versus preâ€‘IRA plans.

Supplyâ€“demand and outlook. Bain estimates global battery demand will climb from ~1,000 GWh in 2023 to ~4,100 GWh by 2030 (4Ã— growth). Beyond passenger EVs, commercial vehicles, tools, and grid storage add to demand. IEA pegs current EV+storage battery market value at ~$120B, potentially near $500B by 2030. U.S. demand is also accelerating: EV leaders (e.g., Tesla) lift shipments while data centers emerge as a new storage buyer. Nearly 95% of incremental power demand growth is expected to be met by PV and wind, which in turn relies on largeâ€‘scale storage. Fastmarkets notes dataâ€‘center power usage has grown ~12% annually since 2017; data centers are installing substantial battery backup and could account for roughly oneâ€‘third of storage demand by 2030. On the supply side, IRAâ€™s $35/kWh production credit draws foreign JV investment and domestic scaleâ€‘ups. Shortâ€‘term challenges persist: rapid tech iteration, heavy capex, and 2023â€™s higher rates/policy uncertainty led to delays or cancellations for some plants. Medium term, demand growth looks robust, but localized gluts and uneven utilization could occur â€” watch for overâ€‘build and intensifying competition.

Representative companies & investment take. The segment spans vehicles, cells, systems, and materials: Tesla (TSLA), Eos Energy (EOSE), Microvast (MVST), American Battery Technology (ABAT), among others. Tesla, an industry bellwether, builds 4680 cells in U.S. gigafactories and sells both residential and grid storage â€” a central node in Americaâ€™s battery map. Valuation, however, already embeds high growth. Eos targets zincâ€‘based storage for gridâ€‘scale safety/longevity, has DOE loan support, and offers high upside with high execution risk. Microvast has straddled U.S./China, a reminder of geopoliticsâ€™ impact on funding and operations. Broadly, policy tailwinds are clear: IRA credits can cut manufacturing cost by >30%; content rules in purchase incentives steer localized supply. Longer term, scale leaders and firms with secured orders should compound best. Beware hype cycles: some storage names rallied on narrative ahead of commercialization â€” differentiate mature, profitable materials leaders from earlyâ€‘stage stories; balance â€œcoreâ€ stable names with a small â€œsatelliteâ€ allocation to higherâ€‘beta growth, per risk tolerance.

Rare Earths & Strategic Metals: Industry Vitamins and Defense Arteries

Section titled â€œRare Earths & Strategic Metals: Industry Vitamins and Defense Arteriesâ€

Industry context and strategic role. â€œRare earthsâ€ (17 elements) are often called the vitamins of modern industry â€” essential for highâ€‘performance permanent magnets (EV motors, wind turbines), avionics, guidance systems, and semiconductors. Strategic metals (e.g., antimony, cobalt, titanium, tungsten) are key to defense/highâ€‘tech. The U.S. Department of Defense (DoD) has repeatedly warned that rare earths are indispensable to advanced weapon systems (Fâ€‘35s, submarines, missiles, UAVs). In practice, the U.S. relies heavily on China: China mines â‰¥60% and processes ~90% of rareâ€‘earth products; 70% of U.S. rareâ€‘earth compounds/metals imports (2020â€“2023) came from China. China is also a major supplier of antimony (armor alloys, fuzes), graphite (battery anodes), and tungsten (AP rounds, tooling). This dependency is viewed as a nationalâ€‘security weak point. In 2025, China tightened controls further on rare earths and magnet exports (declaring uses for products containing heavy RE), heightening global concern. Analysts see it as signaling that Beijing may wield rareâ€‘earth supply as leverage. The U.S. response includes reducing reliance, tariff tools, and larger resource investment.

Supplyâ€“demand and outlook. Rareâ€‘earth demand has surged with EVs and clean energy, while supply growth remains concentrated. Export curbs by key suppliers could cause shortages and price swings. The U.S. is acting on multiple fronts: DoD funding to MP Materials for separation, and to Lynas for heavyâ€‘RE processing in Texas; Defense Production Act (DPA) support for lithium, graphite, nickel, antimony, etc. After China restricted antimony exports in Augâ€‘2024, the Defense Logistics Agency (DLA) expanded procurement plans, reportedly earmarking ~$245M with U.S. Antimony (UAMY) â€” roughly threeâ€‘quarters of annual U.S. imports. Strategic stockpiles are set to expand: reports in Octâ€‘2025 suggested a ~$10B criticalâ€‘minerals reserve to reduce China reliance. Over 2025â€“2030, new projects in Australia/Canada could diversify supply; deepâ€‘sea mining (e.g., The Metals Company targeting nickel/cobalt nodules) may contribute. But permitting, costs, and price cycles complicate investment â€” Chinaâ€™s position remains strong in the near term, with allied cooperation and state support needed to bridge gaps. Geopolitical risk will be persistent; decoupling is partial at best, implying a protracted, uneven supplyâ€‘chain reâ€‘wiring.

Representative companies & investment take. The cohort includes MP Materials (MP), USA Rare Earth (USAR), U.S. Antimony (UAMY), and Ivanhoe Electric (IE). MP â€” owner of Mountain Pass, the only producing U.S. RE mine â€” is core to U.S. revival efforts, building separation and magnet capacity with government backing, and is among the more mature, revenueâ€‘generating names. USA Rare Earth controls Texasâ€™ Round Top deposit (heavy RE + lithium, etc.) and has been bid up postâ€‘listing on strategic value; it remains preâ€‘revenue and high beta. UAMY is one of few North American antimony producers, small in scale but strategically notable given DLA contracts; fundamentals hinge more on policy than on structural growth. Overall, many names are early stage with elevated hype risk. Focus on who can deliver capacity and longâ€‘term offtakes. Policy can whipsaw prices (bans, tariffs, contracts). Resource equities are also rate/commodityâ€‘cycle sensitive; small caps are often first to sell off when the dollar strengthens or commodities fall.

Lithium: The â€œWhite Oilâ€ of the EV Era

Section titled â€œLithium: The â€œWhite Oilâ€ of the EV Eraâ€

Industry context and strategic role. Lithium â€” the â€œwhite oilâ€ of the energyâ€‘transition era â€” is indispensable to Liâ€‘ion batteries. With EVs and storage booming, it has become a strategic resource. The U.S. classifies lithium as critical and sees it as central to EVâ€‘supplyâ€‘chain autonomy. Domestic resource endowment is modest: only one producing site today (Silver Peak brine, NV), far short of needs. Much of U.S. lithium arrives via imports from South America/Australia and is then refined in China. USGS estimates U.S. dependence on lithium compounds exceeded 50% in 2022. Any geopolitical disruption or export control poses EV supply risks. Washington is backing U.S. projects (e.g., DOE loans/guarantees to Lithium Americasâ€™ Thacker Pass; R&D into clay/geothermalâ€‘brine extraction) and tying IRA consumer incentives to sourcing from the U.S. or FTA partners â€” elevating lithiumâ€™s strategic importance.

Supplyâ€“demand and outlook. Lithium saw a rollerâ€‘coaster: a 2021â€“2022 price spike on EV demand, followed by a 2023 correction as supply growth outpaced demand. Fastmarkets estimates 2024 lithium supply up ~22% (China, Australia, South America, Africa), while demand remained strong but temporarily lagged, creating a nearâ€‘term surplus. Medium to long term, the outlook remains positive: global lithium consumption in 2024 is ~220kt LCE (+29% y/y), with EV demand projected to grow 12% annually through 2030. At that pace, 2030 demand could be >3Ã— today. New supply is coming: faster expansions in Australia/South America; Africa could contribute 18% of hardâ€‘rock supply by 2030; U.S. projects (Thacker Pass; Arkansas geothermal brines) may come online 2026â€“2030. Risks: mining projects are multiâ€‘year with tough permitting; U.S. timelines have slipped (e.g., Thacker Pass litigation). Refining is concentrated in China, where cash costs ($8k/t) are well below North America (>$20k/t), meaning ore may still need overseas processing. Closing the midstream gap requires heavy investment in U.S. chemical refining and community/ESG solutions. Tech shifts (solidâ€‘state, sodiumâ€‘ion) could alter mix, but most forecasts still see Liâ€‘ion dominance through 2030 â€” lithiumâ€™s centrality likely persists.

Representative companies & investment take. Upstream and midstream leaders include Albemarle (ALB), Lithium Americas (LAC), and Sigma Lithium (SGML). Albemarle, a top global producer with Chilean brines and Australian rock, is mature and cashâ€‘generative, and plans U.S. refining capacity â€” a core, more defensive exposure, albeit earnings remain priceâ€‘sensitive. Lithium Americas is developing Thacker Pass, the largest U.S. clay resource, with GM investment and government support; 2026 startâ€‘up is targeted, leaving the company in investment mode with valuation reflecting resource optionality â€” monitor progress and capex closely. Sigma operates highâ€‘grade Brazilian assets and has begun trial output; an emerging cashâ€‘flow name but subject to rumorâ€‘driven swings. After prior exuberance, valuations have reset, offering longâ€‘term entry points â€” but differentiate by stage: producers are more resilient; developers offer higher upside with higher risk. A prudent approach is a â€œcore + satelliteâ€ mix: core allocation to leaders for baseline returns, plus smaller satellite bets on highâ€‘beta names for potential alpha. Mind the price cycle â€” build on weakness and avoid chasing peaks.

Macro Backdrop & Strategy: Investing Amid Supplyâ€‘Chain Rewiring

Section titled â€œMacro Backdrop & Strategy: Investing Amid Supplyâ€‘Chain Rewiringâ€

These segments are shaped by macro forces. First, intensifying U.S.â€“China rivalry puts â€œdeâ€‘riskingâ€ and onâ€‘shore manufacturing at the center of security policy, not just economics. JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon has said the U.S. has relied too much on unreliable supply chains for securityâ€‘critical minerals and products â€” a vulnerability now laid bare. Hence the governmentâ€™s industrialâ€‘policy toolkit â€” subsidies, tariffs, CFIUSâ€‘style reviews, and export controls â€” is being deployed to reshape key sectors. Carbonâ€‘neutral commitments also require massive cleanâ€‘energy infrastructure, turboâ€‘charging demand for lithium, cobalt, nickel, rare earths, etc. Meanwhile, geopolitical shocks (trade tensions, conflicts) amplify supply uncertainty; countries increasingly securitize resources (e.g., Chinaâ€™s repeated curbs on criticalâ€‘mineral exports; the U.S. using the NDAA and related measures to prioritize domestic supply). Second, â€œfriendâ€‘shoringâ€ is real: U.S. alliances with resourceâ€‘rich partners (Australia, Canada, parts of Africa) aim to build diversified, lowerâ€‘risk networks (e.g., the Minerals Security Partnership). Expect a more distributed rawâ€‘materials map and more crossâ€‘border opportunities â€” but also local instability and competition with Chinese capital. Third, macro cycles matter: inflation can lift commodity prices and resource cash flows, but higher rates raise project financing costs and compress multiples for growth names. The recent hiking cycle pressured renewables/storage equities; over the long run, however, realâ€‘asset scarcity can trump monetary headwinds if structural shortages emerge. Investors should weigh macro and industry cycles and time entries â€” adding on weakness to policyâ€‘supported quality names can be effective.

Investor Playbook: Balancing Growth and Risk

Section titled â€œInvestor Playbook: Balancing Growth and Riskâ€

Policyâ€‘beneficiary names. Companies with subsidies, orders, or strategic backing (DoD/DOE) enjoy higher earnings visibility: examples include U.S. Antimony with defense contracts, Eos with a DOE loan, and IRAâ€‘benefit U.S. battery manufacturers. Track policy flows and position accordingly â€” but assess whether support is already priced in.

Mediumâ€‘toâ€‘longâ€‘term compounders. Firms with core resources/technology and large addressable markets â€” e.g., Albemarle, MP Materials, Tesla â€” have solid fundamentals and can scale with their sectors. Consider buying on weakness and holding through cycles.

Highâ€‘volatility concepts. Preâ€‘revenue miners and earlyâ€‘tech storage names can be explosive â€” but akin to venture exposure, with binary risks. If participating, keep position sizes modest and use clear risk controls.

Valuation discipline. Hot themes attract capital; some names embed overly optimistic scenarios. Watch P/B, P/S versus peers, and the realism of forward estimates. If fundamentals lag price, consider trimming.

Portfolio mix and diversification. A â€œcoreâ€“satelliteâ€ structure can balance upside and volatility: core in stable leaders, small satellites in higherâ€‘growth, higherâ€‘risk names for potential excess returns.

Learn the basics. Understanding terms like rare earths, spodumene, and storage tech helps judge headline impact. Research and filings remain essential before allocating capital.

In sum, the â€œU.S. Security Indexâ€ mirrors the investment throughâ€‘line of greatâ€‘power competition and energy transition: from resource independence to frontierâ€‘tech selfâ€‘reliance. The theme has strategic tailwinds but also speculative noise. For individual investors, opportunity and risk are two sides of the same coin. Ground decisions in fundamentals, follow policy signals, diversify, and keep a longâ€‘term lens to balance nationalâ€‘security themes with sustainable wealth creation.

item.title: Oracle Teams Up with AMD: Outlook and Risks for AIâ€‘Era Stock Performance
item.content:encoded:
Background: Exploding AI Compute Demand Drives Bigâ€‘Tech Collaboration

Section titled â€œBackground: Exploding AI Compute Demand Drives Bigâ€‘Tech Collaborationâ€

On October 14, Oracle and AMD announced a plan to build an ultraâ€‘scale AI superâ€‘cluster. Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) will begin deploying 50,000 AMD Instinct MI450 GPUs in Q3 2026, with further expansion expected through 2027 and beyond. This would make Oracle the first hyperscaler to adopt AMDâ€™s newest GPUs at scale for external AI compute services. According to launch details, each MI450 provides up to 432 GB of HBM4 and 20 TB/s memory bandwidth, enabling models roughly 50% larger than the prior generation to fit fully in memory.

Oracleâ€™s move targets the explosive growth in compute needs for nextâ€‘generation AI models. Building on years of collaboration with AMD (OCI has offered MI300X services since 2024), Oracle aims to provide enterprise customers with a highâ€‘performance, scalable platform for AI training and inference using an open architecture and the latest hardware.

Beyond technology, markets view this as a strategic play to seize share in the AI wave. Oracle increasingly positions AI as its cloud growth engine. CEO Safra Catz expects OCI revenue to surge 77% YoY to $18B this fiscal year and sees potential to reach $144B over the next four years. Against this backdrop, Oracle is tightening its partnership with AMD to preâ€‘build nextâ€‘gen AI infrastructure â€” a move with major upside but meaningful execution and market risks.

GPU Market Landscape: Nvidia Dominates, AMD Is Catching Up

Section titled â€œGPU Market Landscape: Nvidia Dominates, AMD Is Catching Upâ€

Today, Nvidia supplies over 90% of highâ€‘performance AI GPUs used globally. Most hyperscalers â€” Google, Amazon, Microsoft â€” train AI primarily on Nvidia GPUs and the CUDA software stack. However, rising demand for a second source and more open alternatives is creating opportunity for challengers like AMD.

AMD has invested heavily in dataâ€‘center GPUs. Its Instinct line (e.g., MI250, MI300X) has been trialed in supercomputers and cloud, though historically lagging Nvidia on ecosystem depth and some performance metrics. The new MI450 is a stepâ€‘change in memory capacity and bandwidth, paired with the open ROCm stack, aiming to offer a competitive, more open alternative to Nvidiaâ€™s H100/H200.

Other chipmakers are also pursuing AI acceleration. Broadcom reportedly partnered with OpenAI on custom accelerators, sending Broadcomâ€™s stock up ~10% on the news. Intelâ€™s Gaudi series (via Habana) targets value with competitive priceâ€‘performance. The hardware landscape is diversifying as leading AI firms sign multiâ€‘vendor deals.

Price and supply are critical. Nvidiaâ€™s flagship H100 has traded at $30,000â€“$40,000 per unit (peaking higher during shortages). Reports suggest AMD has priced MI300 series more aggressively (around ~$10,000 for large customers). Intel markets Gaudi at roughly half the cost of Nvidia alternatives. Hyperscalers are incentivized to diversify for cost control, creating an opening for AMD â€” though potentially at lower margins.

Bottom line: Nvidia remains dominant near term, but AMDâ€™s technical progress and alliances should lift its share over the next few years.

Cloud Competition: Oracleâ€™s Opportunities and Challenges

Section titled â€œCloud Competition: Oracleâ€™s Opportunities and Challengesâ€

Oracle is a relative latecomer to cloud vs. AWS, Azure, and GCP. The AI surge, however, is a chance to move faster: many enterprises want to train large models and deploy generative AI but face tight GPU supply, high costs, and singleâ€‘vendor risk on mainstream clouds. Oracleâ€™s bet on massive AMD GPU clusters aims to differentiate with open standards and better priceâ€‘performance, while attracting multiâ€‘cloud customers who donâ€™t want to rely on a single provider.

Oracleâ€™s â€œAllâ€‘in on AIâ€ strategy is already yielding big wins. Since 2023, Oracle has secured multiple multiâ€‘billionâ€‘dollar AI cloud contracts. Market chatter has also suggested a fiveâ€‘year, upâ€‘toâ€‘$300B agreement with OpenAI to coâ€‘build 4.5 GW of dataâ€‘center capacity â€” reportedly the largest cloud contract ever. While not officially disclosed, these reports spurred investor optimism; when the rumor emerged in September, Oracleâ€™s stock jumped ~25% after hours.

Even setting giant deals aside, AI demand is driving OCIâ€™s guidance higher: this year, Oracle raised its OCI growth outlook from 70% to 77%. Founder Larry Ellison said â€œAI changes everything,â€ and expects AI to materially expand cloud demand in coming years. On the application layer, Oracle plans â€œAI Databaseâ€ offerings that integrate models like ChatGPT, Claude, and Gemini directly into Oracle Database to simplify enterprise access â€” a classic Oracle strength that could complement its underlying compute buildâ€‘out.

Challenges remain. The Big Three clouds are not standing still: AWS continues to procure Nvidia GPUs and expand Trainium/Inferentia; Azure is tied closely with OpenAI and works with multiple silicon partners; Google has TPUs plus Nvidia options. Competing with established ecosystems and deep capital pools is hard. Meanwhile, buying 50,000 GPUs entails massive capex and technical risk; if AI demand slows or customers underutilize capacity, Oracle could be left with excess.

Net: Oracleâ€™s AIâ€‘cloud push is a highâ€‘risk, highâ€‘reward wager â€” one that could materially expand its cloud footprint and share price if executed well.

Near Term (6 Months): Elevated Sentiment, Likely Consolidation

Long-term investing follows the principle of â€œsimplicity is the ultimate sophisticationâ€: ordinary investors can achieve substantial asset growth simply by holding one or two U.S. stock index funds over the long run. As a composite index of the 500 largest companies by market capitalization in the U.S. stock market, the S&P 500 covers major industries such as information technology, consumer discretionary, financials, and healthcare, and is widely regarded as a barometer of the overall performance of the U.S. stock market. For instance, the legendary investor Warren Buffett has repeatedly recommended S&P 500 index funds and stipulated in his will that 90% of his personal assets be invested in them, demonstrating his confidence in the indexâ€™s long-term, stable returns.

Depending on their risk appetite, investors can also add a Nasdaq 100 index fund and an information technology sector fund (VGT) to construct a â€œtripodâ€ portfolio of U.S. stock index funds. Below, we introduce these three types of index funds worthy of long-term holding and explain how to allocate them according to a 5:2:1 ratio.

S&P 500 Index Fund: The Cornerstone of the U.S. Stock Market

Section titled â€œS&P 500 Index Fund: The Cornerstone of the U.S. Stock Marketâ€

The S&P 500 Index is composed of the 500 largest U.S. public companies by market capitalization, spanning a wide range of sectors from technology and consumer goods to energy and utilities. Due to its diversified components and dispersed weights, the S&P 500 index fund is often considered the primary core asset for investing in the U.S. stock market. Historical data shows that the S&P 500 has a long-term annualized return of around 10%, with relatively moderate volatility, making it suitable for most investors seeking stable growth.

  • Diversification: Covering 500 companies, it does not rely on individual stocks, thus fully diversifying unsystematic risk. The index components account for the vast majority of the U.S. stock marketâ€™s capitalization, effectively allowing one to â€œbuy the U.S. economy in one click.â€
  • Long-term Stable Growth: It has consistently reached new highs through multiple bull and bear cycles, with a high probability of achieving positive returns over long rolling periods.
  • Endorsement by Investment Masters: Many investment gurus advocate for regular investment in S&P 500 index funds; Buffett has long recommended a â€œbuy and holdâ€ strategy.

It is important to note that S&P 500 index funds are still subject to periodic drawdowns due to economic cycles, but their volatility risk is lower compared to narrower-based indices. For investors with average risk tolerance, an S&P 500 index fund can serve as a single, lifelong holding.

Nasdaq 100 Index Fund: High-Growth Opportunities in Tech Leaders

Section titled â€œNasdaq 100 Index Fund: High-Growth Opportunities in Tech Leadersâ€

The Nasdaq-100 Index consists of the 100 largest non-financial companies listed on the Nasdaq Stock Market and is renowned for its high weighting in technology stocks. The index includes tech giants such as Apple, Microsoft, Alphabet (Googleâ€™s parent company), Amazon, and Nvidia. By providing concentrated exposure to high-growth sectors, the Nasdaq-100 has delivered a significantly higher annualized total return than the S&P 500 over the past few decades.

The characteristics of a Nasdaq 100 index fund can be summarized as follows:

  • Heavy Allocation to Tech Growth: A high proportion of high-growth sectors like information technology results in long-term returns that often outperform the broader market.
  • Higher Volatility: High returns are accompanied by high volatility, with more severe drawdowns during market downturns (e.g., the periods of 2000â€“2002 and 2022).
  • Bias Towards Emerging Industries: Components are predominantly from fields like technology, communication services, and consumer discretionary, aligning with future trends but exhibiting weaker defensive capabilities.

In summary, the Nasdaq 100 index fund offers an opportunity to share in the growth of Americaâ€™s leading technology companies. Its excellent long-term returns come with greater short-term volatility, making it suitable for investors with a certain level of risk tolerance who can withstand significant fluctuations in net asset value.

Information Technology Sector Fund (VGT): Capturing the Overall Dividends of the Tech Industry

Section titled â€œInformation Technology Sector Fund (VGT): Capturing the Overall Dividends of the Tech Industryâ€

Information technology sector funds focus on investing in the IT industry. Take Vanguardâ€™s Information Technology ETF (ticker: VGT) as an example: VGT tracks the MSCI US IMI Information Technology 25/50 Index, holding over 300 IT company stocks, including large-cap tech firms like Nvidia, Apple, Microsoft, and Broadcom, as well as numerous small and mid-cap tech companies. Similar to the Nasdaq 100, VGT is highly concentrated in the technology sector but offers broader coverage (not limited to Nasdaq-listed companies).

The purpose of including an IT sector fund in a portfolio is to capture the excess returns of the technology industry. Over the past decade, VGT has at times outperformed the Nasdaq 100, as small and mid-cap tech stocks contributed additional gains during tech booms. However, higher returns come with higher risks. The tech sector is often the first to be hit during interest rate hikes or market panics, and pure-tech ETFs experience larger drawdowns in volatile markets. During the 2022 tech bear market, VGTâ€™s maximum drawdown was nearly -35%, slightly higher than the Nasdaq 100â€™s maximum drawdown during the same period.

This type of fund is more suitable for investors who are highly optimistic about the future of technology and have a strong personal risk tolerance. For those who have already achieved financial freedom or are experienced investors, a moderate allocation to pursue higher returns is feasible. However, ordinary investors with lower risk appetites can choose not to allocate to it or to reduce their allocation.

The 5:2:1 Allocation Strategy and Periodic Rebalancing

Section titled â€œThe 5:2:1 Allocation Strategy and Periodic Rebalancingâ€

For the three types of index funds discussed above, a straightforward portfolio strategy is to allocate them in a 5:2:1 ratio: approximately 62.5% to the S&P 500, 25% to the Nasdaq 100, and 12.5% to an information technology sector fund. The philosophy is as follows:

  • Core Holding (approx. 50%): The S&P 500 provides a stable foundation and broad diversification, capturing the average growth of the U.S. economy.
  • Satellite Holding (approx. 20%): The Nasdaq 100 enhances the portfolioâ€™s long-term returns, sharing in the growth of large-cap tech.
  • Aggressive Holding (approx. 10%): The IT sector fund increases aggressiveness, providing greater elasticity during favorable economic cycles.

This portfolio balances stability and aggressiveness and can be fine-tuned according to individual circumstances. For example, conservative investors can reduce the weighting of the Nasdaq and tech funds (e.g., to 7:2:1 or 8:1:1), while aggressive investors can moderately increase the aggressive portion. The portfolio should be periodically rebalanced based on market changes and financial goals to restore the asset weights to their preset levels, thereby maintaining the desired risk-return profile.

Conclusion

Section titled â€œConclusionâ€

The S&P 500, Nasdaq 100, and information technology sector funds can form a three-pronged portfolio for long-term holding, combining a comprehensive and stable core with a high-growth engine that capitalizes on the technology wave. By adopting an appropriate allocation ratio based on their risk tolerance, and by adhering to a long-term investment strategy with periodic rebalancing, most investors can expect to achieve favorable risk-adjusted returns, fostering long-term wealth appreciation. Instead of frequent market timing and stock picking, it is more effective to build a simple and efficient index fund portfolio and hold it for the long term, navigating through bull and bear markets.

item.title: Rapidly Develop a HarmonyOS 6 Bluetooth Device Management App with Claude Code: Bluetooth Interaction, ArkTS Compilation Fixes, and TDD/BDD Practices
item.content:encoded:
Rapidly Develop a HarmonyOS 6 Bluetooth Device Management App with Claude Code: Bluetooth Interaction, ArkTS Compilation Fixes, and TDD/BDD Practices

Section titled â€œRapidly Develop a HarmonyOS 6 Bluetooth Device Management App with Claude Code: Bluetooth Interaction, ArkTS Compilation Fixes, and TDD/BDD Practicesâ€

This article demonstrates how to quickly develop a Bluetooth device management app for Huaweiâ€™s HarmonyOS 6 using Claude Code. It covers typical features such as receiving Bluetooth advertisements, connecting to devices, setting the time, synchronizing status, performing infusions, and retrieving logs. The article also focuses on strategies for fixing ArkTS compilation errors and implementing TDD/BDD-oriented testing.

â€” Suitable for teams aiming to build BLE device applications through a â€œwrite, test, iterate quicklyâ€ approach.

1. Development Goals and Device Protocol Overview

Section titled â€œ1. Development Goals and Device Protocol Overviewâ€
  • Target Device: A Bluetooth device.
  • Typical Commands:
    • Read status, synchronize time, perform infusion, read records.

Implementation Files and Data Models:

  • entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleService.ets: An all-in-one wrapper for scanning and discovery, connection, notifications, and command sending.
  • entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleCommand.ets: Command construction (including CRC, length, and time/dose encoding).
  • entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleResponseParser.ets: Response parsing.
  • entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleAdvertisingParser.ets: Advertising data parsing (local name, UUID, manufacturer data, etc.).

2. How Claude Code Accelerates Native ArkTS Development

Section titled â€œ2. How Claude Code Accelerates Native ArkTS Developmentâ€
  • Code Navigation and Refactoring:
    • Quickly locate BLE-related entry points, cross-references, and dependencies using commands; maintain consistency with batch renaming and interface extraction.
  • Assisted Fixing of ArkTS Compilation Warnings/Errors:
    • Automatically points out rule violations like arkts-no-spread and unknown/any, suggesting replacement code and type completion.
  • Generating Test Skeletons and Adding Assertions:
    • Quickly create and extend unit tests and UI integration tests based on Hypium.

By combining these capabilities, a high-frequency feedback loop of â€œmodify â†’ run tests â†’ analyze logs â†’ fix/refactorâ€ can be established, significantly shortening the cycle from protocol design to an end-to-end working application.

3. Detailed Breakdown of the Bluetooth Interaction Flow

Section titled â€œ3. Detailed Breakdown of the Bluetooth Interaction Flowâ€

1. Receiving Bluetooth Advertisements (Scanning and Parsing)

Section titled â€œ1. Receiving Bluetooth Advertisements (Scanning and Parsing)â€
  • Multi-path Scanning (HarmonyOS API v15+):
    • Entry Point: entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleService.ets startScan(...)
    • Event: BLEDeviceFind is continuously reported, internally using BleAdvertisingParser to parse the local name, service UUID, manufacturer data, etc.
  • Advertising Parsing: entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleAdvertisingParser.ets
    • Covers major AD types like Flags, Complete/Incomplete UUIDs, and Manufacturer Specific Data, making it easy to quickly identify the target device.

Associated Discovery Service: entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleDiscoveryService.ets encapsulates the discovery list, sorting by RSSI, automatic stopping on timeout, and a â€œtrusted deviceâ€ caching strategy. The UI side can directly subscribe to status/result callbacks.

2. Connecting to a Device and Enabling Notifications

Section titled â€œ2. Connecting to a Device and Enabling Notificationsâ€
  • After connecting and discovering services, you must â€œsubscribe, then enable notifications, then read once moreâ€ before writing:
    • Enable Notifications: entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleService.ets
      • First, subscribe to the callback: gattClient.on('BLECharacteristicChange', ...)
      • Then, enable it: setCharacteristicChangeNotification(..., true)
      • Optionally, perform a readCharacteristicValue once to â€œwarm upâ€ the notification channel (required by some devices).
  • Notification Callback: entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleService.ets onCharacteristicChanged(...)
    • Use lowercase UUID comparison to avoid misses due to case differences.
    • Convert characteristic.characteristicValue to an ArrayBuffer before dispatching to a pending callback or a unified protocol parser.

3. Sending and Debugging Commands

Section titled â€œ3. Sending and Debugging Commandsâ€
  • Sending a Write: entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleService.ets sendCommand(...)
    • ArkTS disables object spreading (no-spread), so characteristicValue must be modified directly before writing.
    • Uniformly output hexadecimal strings for easier troubleshooting: BleCommand.toHexString(...)
  • Command Construction:
    • Read Status: entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleCommand.ets
    • Synchronize Time: entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleCommand.ets
    • Infusion Command: entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleCommand.ets (dose Ã— 1000 converted to an integer, written in little-endian).

4. Synchronizing Time and Reading Status

Section titled â€œ4. Synchronizing Time and Reading Statusâ€
  • Synchronize Time: entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleService.ets, writes 0xA7 containing year, month, day, week, hour, minute, and second, then verifies through the notification channel upon completion.
  • Read Status: entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleService.ets â†’ Wait for notification â†’ Parse: entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleResponseParser.ets
    • Parses battery status, voltage/charge, remaining dose, single/daily limits, alarm bits, todayâ€™s usage, maximum log entries, etc.

5. Infusion

Section titled â€œ5. Infusionâ€
  • entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleService.ets calls buildInjectionCommand(dose).
  • entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleCommand.ets: The dose is encoded as a 4-byte little-endian integer with a precision of 1/1000, accommodating â€œlarge/high-precision doseâ€ scenarios.
  • Recommendations:
    • Perform pre-validation against the single/daily limits from the status, and split into packets or send in multiple parts if necessary.
    • Pay attention to MTU (typically 20 bytes) limitations and command length design.

6. Retrieving Logs (Record Parsing)

Section titled â€œ6. Retrieving Logs (Record Parsing)â€
  • Notification Handling Dispatch: entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleService.ets processReceivedData(...)
    • The â€œ path calls record parsing: entry/src/main/ets/utils/BleResponseParser.ets parseRecord(...)
    • Supports two types of structured data: injection records and operation records.
  • If you need to â€œfetch historical records by index/type,â€ you can add a READ_RECORD_WITH_TYPE constructor in BleCommand (a template is commented out in the project), which seamlessly integrates with the parsing logic above.

4. ArkTS Compilation Errors and Key Fixes

Section titled â€œ4. ArkTS Compilation Errors and Key Fixesâ€

Summary Document: docs/ble-arkts-fix-summary.md

  • Missing Class Properties:
    • For example, if connectionPromiseResolvers is not declared, it needs to be added as Map<string, () => void> for external resolution of connection Promises.
  • arkts-no-spread:
    • Object spreading is forbidden when writing characteristic values. Directly modify existing.characteristicValue = ... (see the BleService.ets section).
  • unknown/any and Loose Literals:
    • In notification callbacks, remove temporary Record<string, string>/unknown assertions and use strong typing instead.
  • Notification Matching and Logging:
    • Use lowercase UUID comparison and detailed logging of service/char UUID and hexadecimal payloads for easier on-site debugging.

These fixes, without changing business semantics, make the code satisfy both ArkTS semantics and Lint rules, resulting in a stable and maintainable build.

5. TDD and BDD Testing Practices

Section titled â€œ5. TDD and BDD Testing Practicesâ€

1. Unit Testing (TDD)

Section titled â€œ1. Unit Testing (TDD)â€
  • Device Discovery and Caching:
    • entry/src/ohosTest/ets/test/BleDiscoveryService.test.ets
    • entry/src/ohosTest/ets/test/DeviceCache.test.ets
  • Coverage Points:
    • Scan status flow, filtering by name, RSSI sorting, automatic stopping.
    • Trusted device marking, cache clearing, capacity limits, expiration statistics, etc.
  • Running Tests:
    • hvigor test
    • Filter by file: hvigor test --filter BleDiscoveryService

2. Behavior-Driven Development (BDD) and UI Integration

Section titled â€œ2. Behavior-Driven Development (BDD) and UI Integrationâ€
  • Scenario Use Case: entry/src/ohosTest/ets/test/BleUIIntegration.test.ets
    • Start â†’ Begin Scan â†’ Discover Device â†’ Connect â†’ Sync Time/Refresh Status/Send Infusion â†’ Disconnect.
    • Utilizes @kit.TestKitâ€™s Driver to find buttons, click, and assert, ensuring an end-to-end path â€œfrom UI to protocol.â€
  • Running Tests:
    • Full integration test: hvigor test --integration

3. Assertions and Timeout Strategies

Section titled â€œ3. Assertions and Timeout Strategiesâ€
  • Most BLE steps are asynchronous callbacks: set reasonable timeouts for scanning/connecting/writing/notifications (e.g., 5â€“15s) to avoid false positives.
  • For critical UI text and buttons, try finding them multiple times to improve stability.
  • Use hexadecimal logs as an assertion aid (see BleService.ets/BleService.ets).

6. Practical Advice and Common Pitfalls

Section titled â€œ6. Practical Advice and Common Pitfallsâ€
  • Notification Order and â€œWarm-upâ€:
    • The sequence â€œsubscribe â†’ enable notifications â†’ read onceâ€ can significantly improve the success rate of the first downstream response for some devices.
  • MTU and Command Length:
    • A typical BLE 4.2 MTU is only 20 bytes. Complex commands need to be split or the negotiation strategy on the device/firmware side needs to be upgraded.
  • Little-Endian Encoding and CRC:
    • The total command length, field encoding, and CRC16 (CCITT/False) calculation must be strictly aligned with the firmware.
  • Use HiLog Instead of console:
    • Use a unified domain/tag and %{public} output (see docs/hilog-migration-summary.md) for easier offline and on-site troubleshooting.
  • Permissions and Bluetooth Status:
    • Unified entry point: entry/src/main/ets/utils/BlePermissionManager.ets ensureBleReady(...). Handle permissions and adapter status all at once before starting a scan.

7. Conclusion and Next Steps

Section titled â€œ7. Conclusion and Next Stepsâ€

Thanks to Claude Codeâ€™s â€œcode navigation + compilation repair + test generationâ€ features, we completed the entire cycle from protocol design to an end-to-end working solution with minimal back-and-forth:

  • Bluetooth Interaction: The full chain of scanning, connecting, notifications, commands, and record parsing is connected.
  • ArkTS Fixes: Strictly follows semantics and Lint rules for a stable build.
  • TDD/BDD: Unit and UI integration tests cover major scenarios, facilitating continuous regression.

Recommended Next Steps:

  • Add the READ_RECORD_WITH_TYPE command constructor in BleCommand to integrate with the existing parser and complete the â€œfetch logs by indexâ€ feature.
  • Introduce more granular ViewModel layer state management and data persistence to create a complete â€œcloud-device-edgeâ€ loop with record synchronization.
  • Refine exception codes and retry strategies to enhance robustness during network disconnection/reconnection.

TL;DR

Section titled â€œTL;DRâ€

The HarmonyOS BLE API version used in my previous project (v14 and earlier) had limitations such as single-scan restrictions and incomplete resource management.

Now, using Claude Code to generate and modify code, I was able to understand and automatically migrate to the latest HarmonyOS BLE API v15+, enabling multi-scan and more robust connection management.

Finally, I documented the complete migration process from v14 to v15+, focusing on multi-scan support, advertising data parsing, and connection management optimization.

Background

Section titled â€œBackgroundâ€

In the HarmonyOS ecosystem, BLE (Bluetooth Low Energy) is a crucial technology for interconnecting smart devices. As application demands have grown, the limitation of single-scan has become increasingly apparent, especially in scenarios requiring simultaneous scanning for multiple devices or services.

HarmonyOS introduced multi-scan support in API version 15, allowing applications to create multiple independent scanning instances, thereby improving resource management and scanning flexibility.

However, the existing project code was still based on the old API, leading to the following issues:

  1. Single-Scan Limitation: Only one scanning task could be performed at a time, failing to meet the demand for multi-device scanning.
  2. Incomplete Resource Management: Scanner instances were not managed independently, causing state confusion.
  3. Lack of Advertising Data Parsing: Scan results did not parse advertising data, affecting device information retrieval.
  4. Simple Connection Management: The absence of retry and automatic reconnection mechanisms compromised connection stability.

Objective

Section titled â€œObjectiveâ€

Based on the latest HarmonyOS BLE API v15+, refactor the existing BLE service code to achieve the following goals:

  1. Multi-Scan Support: Allow multiple scanning tasks to run simultaneously, with each task managed independently.
  2. Independent Resource Management: Each scanner instance is controlled independently to avoid conflicts.
  3. Complete Advertising Data Parsing: Implement parsing of BLE advertising data.
  4. Enhanced Connection Management: Implement connection retry and automatic reconnection mechanisms to improve connection stability.
  5. Modern Asynchronous Handling: Use Promise/async-await to handle asynchronous BLE operations.

Migration Process

1. Read Official Documentation

Can AI truly develop a website independently now? This article shares a real experiment where three AI tools, each with a specific role, collaborated to complete the end-to-end development of a ToDo list application. We assigned them the following roles:

  • Codex: Project Manager (for requirements and acceptance criteria)
  • Claude Code: Development and Test Engineer
  • Gemini CLI: Code Review and Documentation Engineer

This process formed a closed-loop AI collaboration, from â€œRequirements Analysis -> Feature Implementation -> Automated Testing -> Review and Improvement -> Documentation.â€

1. Codex: The AI Project Manager Defines the Requirements

Section titled â€œ1. Codex: The AI Project Manager Defines the Requirementsâ€

Codex excels at transforming vague ideas into structured requirements. We gave it the concept of a â€œto-do list websiteâ€ and asked it to:

  • Output a functional requirements document
  • List quantitative acceptance criteria for each feature
  • Add exception and boundary scenarios

Example Prompt:

Codex produced content covering:

  • Basic functions: Add task / Mark as complete / Delete task
  • Task status display and update logic
  • Acceptance criteria examples:
    • The task should appear in the list immediately after being added.
    • Completed tasks should be styled differently from uncompleted ones.
    • The list should refresh instantly after deletion with no residual data.
  • Exception handling: Empty input, duplicate tasks, invalid characters, etc.

Key takeaways:

  • The more specific the prompt, the more complete the generated requirements.
  • Clearly defining â€œbehavior + criteriaâ€ can be directly converted into test cases.

2. Claude Code: The AI Development Engineer Generates and Executes Code

Section titled â€œ2. Claude Code: The AI Development Engineer Generates and Executes Codeâ€

Claude Code received the requirements document and started implementing the frontend, backend, and basic tests using React + Node/Express:

  • Frontend: Task input, display, status switching, and deletion interactions
  • Backend: Simple in-memory data storage + REST API (Create/Read/Update/Delete)
  • Supporting documents: README (running steps, dependency instructions)
  • Automated tests: Simulate adding/marking/deleting and assert status and list length

Example Prompt:

Claudeâ€™s execution characteristics:

  • Generated files by module (components, services, tests)
  • Ran tests while writing code, adjusting if they failed
  • Found and fixed minor issues, such as the list not refreshing immediately after deletion

Shortcomings (to be improved):

  • The initial UI was quite plain.
  • Task filtering/searching was not yet implemented.
  • Lacked persistence (in-memory only).

3. Gemini CLI: The AI Code Reviewer Inspects and Improves

Section titled â€œ3. Gemini CLI: The AI Code Reviewer Inspects and Improvesâ€

Gemini CLI, as the review and summarization role, focused on:

  • Verifying if the functionality met the requirements and acceptance criteria
  • Pointing out gaps and areas for improvement
  • Generating a project summary and technical documentation

Example Prompt:

Example improvement suggestions from Gemini:

  • Add task filtering: All / Incomplete / Completed
  • Add search or pagination to handle a large number of tasks
  • UI enhancements: Status colors, placeholder text for empty lists, button accessibility
  • Introduce data persistence (file / SQLite / IndexedDB / LocalStorage)
  • Add error messages and input validation feedback
  • Add E2E tests (e.g., using Playwright)

Generated technical documentation structure (summary):

  • Project Introduction
  • Feature List and Corresponding Implementation
  • Tech Stack: React (Frontend SPA) + Axios (API calls) + Express (REST service)
  • Running Steps: Install dependencies -> Start backend -> Start frontend -> Access local port
  • Testing Instructions: Functional tests + extensible integration tests
  • Future Plans: Status filtering, persistence, permissions, multi-user support, multi-device adaptation

4. Summary of the Collaborative Loopâ€™s Value

Section titled â€œ4. Summary of the Collaborative Loopâ€™s Valueâ€

Advantages:

  • Clear roles: A smooth flow from requirements â†’ implementation â†’ review â†’ documentation
  • Traceability: Acceptance criteria directly map to tests
  • Efficiency: Humans primarily focus on â€œsupervision + directionâ€ rather than tedious, repetitive work
  • Quality: Multiple AI model perspectives reduce oversights

Current limitations:

  • Complex business modeling still requires human abstraction.
  • Deeper performance, security, and concurrency issues still need professional evaluation.
  • Limited UI/UX innovation (biased towards functional correctness).

5. Directions for Further Iteration

Section titled â€œ5. Directions for Further Iterationâ€

Suggested priorities for expansion:

  1. Feature Layer: Status filtering / search / bulk operations / due dates / priorities
  2. Data Layer: Persistence (SQLite/Prisma) + simple identity system

item.title: Interpreting and Analyzing OpenAI's Latest Paper 'How People Use ChatGPT'
item.content:encoded:
Introduction: A Global AI Revolution and Our Cognitive Blind Spots

Section titled â€œIntroduction: A Global AI Revolution and Our Cognitive Blind Spotsâ€

In November 2022, OpenAI released its groundbreaking product, ChatGPT, to the public. Since its debut, the toolâ€™s adoption rate has been astonishing. A working paper from the National Bureau of Economic Research (NBER Working Paper 34255), â€œHow People Use ChatGPT,â€ indicates that as of July 2025, ChatGPT had reached 700 million weekly active users, with over 2.5 billion messages exchanged daily, equivalent to approximately 29,000 messages per second. This unprecedented global diffusion rate led to its adoption by about 10% of the worldâ€™s adult population within just a few years. However, public and media understanding of this phenomenon often remains superficial. Most people view ChatGPT as a tool for content creation, programming, or simple chat, while its deeper social, economic, and human impacts remain hidden beneath the surface of everyday use.

This report will center on this pioneering study, co-authored by OpenAIâ€™s research team and NBER, aiming to provide a comprehensive, multi-dimensional, in-depth interpretation and critical analysis. The report will go beyond the paperâ€™s data presentation, clarifying contradictions between different studies and media reports through multi-party fact-checking, and exploring the profound trends, causal relationships, and potential impacts on future society embedded in these data from economic, sociological, and human motivation perspectives. Ultimately, this report will offer a rigorous yet insightful panoramic view of AI usage for the general reader, presented in an accessible style.

Part One: ChatGPTâ€™s Phenomenal Growth: Multi-Party Verification of Facts and Data

Section titled â€œPart One: ChatGPTâ€™s Phenomenal Growth: Multi-Party Verification of Facts and Dataâ€

1.1 Core Data and Scale: Unprecedented AI Diffusion

Section titled â€œ1.1 Core Data and Scale: Unprecedented AI Diffusionâ€

The NBER working paper provides core data on ChatGPTâ€™s growth. The report shows that from its release in November 2022 to July 2025, its weekly active users grew from millions to 700 million. Concurrently, daily messages soared from zero to over 2.5 billion. This growth rate not only far surpasses traditional technologies, such as Facebook taking four and a half years to reach 100 million users, but is also unparalleled in the field of AI technology. Other third-party statistical platforms, such as DemandSage, Nerdynav, and Seoprofy, in their reports published in mid-2025 or September, further confirmed this phenomenon. Data from these platforms indicate that ChatGPTâ€™s weekly active users have reached or exceeded 800 million, with over 1 billion daily queries.

It is worth noting that there is a slight difference between the NBER reportâ€™s user count (700 million) and third-party reports (800 million). This discrepancy is not a contradiction in data but rather a direct reflection of the unprecedented exponential growth rate of AI technology. The technology is developing so rapidly that any static snapshot in time struggles to fully capture its dynamic entirety. The reportâ€™s data from July 2025 will be surpassed by higher figures in just a few weeks or months. This indicates that when analyzing the impact of AI, a dynamic rather than static perspective must be adopted. This speed itself is the most powerful signal of its disruptive impact on economic and social structures.

1.2 The Rise of Non-Work Uses: A New Perspective on AI Value

Section titled â€œ1.2 The Rise of Non-Work Uses: A New Perspective on AI Valueâ€

For a long time, economic analysis of AI primarily focused on its impact on the productivity of â€œpaid work.â€ However, the NBER report challenges this traditional narrative through its core data. Table 1 of the report clearly shows that from June 2024 to June 2025, the proportion of non-work-related messages on ChatGPT surged from 53% to 73%. This indicates that although the absolute number of work-related messages also continued to grow (from 213 million daily in June 2024 to 716 million daily in June 2025), its growth rate was far outpaced by non-work uses.

This shift in value reveals AIâ€™s broader impact on human society. AIâ€™s value is not only reflected in improving corporate efficiency but also creates immense value for ordinary people through â€œhome productionâ€ and â€œconsumer surplus.â€ For example, Collis and Brynjolfsson (2025) estimate that in 2024 alone, US consumers gained up to $97 billion in surplus value through generative AI. This finding suggests that AIâ€™s scale in improving personal quality of life, time management, and non-economic activity efficiency may be comparable to, or even greater than, its impact on workplace productivity. This shift prompts us to rethink the true value of AI: it is evolving from a mere productivity tool into a â€œlife toolâ€ that profoundly affects our daily lives.

Part Two: Understanding User Behavior: Deconstructing Core Uses and Analyzing Deep Motivations

Section titled â€œPart Two: Understanding User Behavior: Deconstructing Core Uses and Analyzing Deep Motivationsâ€

2.1 The â€œThree Pillarsâ€: The Popular Logic of Practical Guidance, Information Seeking, and Writing

Section titled â€œ2.1 The â€œThree Pillarsâ€: The Popular Logic of Practical Guidance, Information Seeking, and Writingâ€

The NBER report, through its innovative automated classification method, provides us with detailed insights into user behavior. The report points out that nearly 80% of ChatGPT user conversations are concentrated in three core categories: Practical Guidance, Seeking Information, and Writing.

Among these, practical guidance is currently the most common use case, encompassing a wide range of activities such as tutoring and teaching, operational instructions, and creative ideation. Of particular note, educational uses (e.g., tutoring/teaching) account for as high as 10% of all messages, demonstrating AIâ€™s enormous potential in the education sector. Information seeking use cases are growing rapidly and are considered a powerful alternative to traditional search engines. This reflects usersâ€™ increasing demand for instant, integrated answers, rather than just traditional link lists.

To understand user behavior more deeply, the report proposes a unique classification framework: â€œAskingâ€ (asking questions/seeking advice) versus â€œDoingâ€ (executing tasks/creating). Data shows that â€œAskingâ€ messages are growing faster than â€œDoingâ€ and have higher user satisfaction. This trend is not accidental. Whether seeking practical guidance (â€œHow to cook?â€) or obtaining information (â€œWhat is quantum mechanics?â€), the core driving force is to make better decisions and more effectively acquire and process information. This aligns with the NBER reportâ€™s finding that â€œAskingâ€ messages are more favored by highly educated and high-income users, as high-quality decision-making is key to improving productivity in knowledge-intensive work. This finding suggests that ChatGPTâ€™s true value may lie more in its role as a human â€œcognitive co-pilotâ€ to enhance decision-making and cognitive abilities, rather than as a â€œlabor substituteâ€ to automate tasks.

2.2 Writing: A Misunderstood Core Value of Work

Section titled â€œ2.2 Writing: A Misunderstood Core Value of Workâ€

Among all work-related messages, writing is the highest-proportion use case, accounting for an average of 40%. This data seems to confirm many peopleâ€™s concerns that AI will completely replace human writers. However, the report delves deeper to reveal a crucial detail: among all â€œwritingâ€ messages, about two-thirds of the tasks are not â€œfrom scratchâ€ creation, but rather modification, editing, summarization, and translation of user-provided text.

This finding presents a subtle contrast to common perceptions. It indicates that in actual work, AIâ€™s role is more about â€œoptimizationâ€ than â€œreplacement.â€ It helps humans refine existing ideas and content, rather than completely taking over. This finding echoes enterprise AI use cases in reports from companies like IBM and Moveworks. These use cases emphasize AIâ€™s assistive role in content creation, such as generating ad copy drafts, email first drafts, or extracting key information from lengthy documents. This suggests that future workflows will be â€œhuman-AI collaboration,â€ where AI frees humans from repetitive, low-value â€œwritingâ€ tasks, allowing them to focus more on higher-level thinking, strategy, and creativity.

Part Three: Correction and Reflection: The Truth About Controversial Uses and Cognitive Biases

Section titled â€œPart Three: Correction and Reflection: The Truth About Controversial Uses and Cognitive Biasesâ€

3.1 Programming and Companionship: Media-Amplified Use Cases and Data Reality

Section titled â€œ3.1 Programming and Companionship: Media-Amplified Use Cases and Data Realityâ€

Regarding the prevalence of certain specific use cases, the NBER reportâ€™s findings differ significantly from some mainstream media narratives, revealing the complex reality of platform positioning and cognitive biases.

First, programming use cases. The NBER report indicates that programming-related messages account for only 4.2% of all messages on ChatGPT. This contrasts sharply with Handa et al.â€™s research on another AI assistant, Claude, which showed programming-related use cases as high as 33% in work scenarios.

Second, emotional companionship. The NBER report found that emotional companionship (relationships and personal reflection) accounted for only 1.9%, and games and role-playing for 0.4%, totaling a very small proportion. This is a stark contrast to Zao-Sanders and many media reports that list emotional companionship as a primary AI use case.

Why such a significant data gap? A major reason is the difference in platform positioning and user groups. Anthropicâ€™s Claude platform is designed to be more geared towards technical and enterprise users, while Microsoftâ€™s Copilot is deeply integrated into office software like Microsoft 365. In contrast, ChatGPT, as a general consumer-grade platform, has a broader user profile, leading to a relatively lower proportion of vertical use cases like programming. Furthermore, media reports about AI emotional companionship, virtual girlfriends, or â€œdangerousâ€ interactions often receive disproportionate attention due to their sensational nature. This â€œsurvivor biasâ€ leads to a serious overestimation of the universality of these use cases by the public. The NBER report, through large-scale, anonymous first-hand data, provides us with a more factual panoramic view, showing that these use cases remain niche on the consumer side.

3.2 Gender and Age Gap: A Dynamically Changing Social Landscape

Section titled â€œ3.2 Gender and Age Gap: A Dynamically Changing Social Landscapeâ€

Regarding the demographic composition of AI user groups, especially the gender gap, there are also subtle differences between various studies. The NBER report points out that in the early days of ChatGPTâ€™s release (late 2022), the user group was indeed predominantly male, with 80% of active users having typical male names. However, the report shows that this is a rapidly changing dynamic trend. By June 2025, this proportion had dropped to 48%, with female users even slightly outnumbering males. This trend aligns with the finding of accelerated AI user growth in low-income countries.

However, other third-party reports, such as those from Deloitte, Pew Research, and eWeek in 2025, still indicate a significant gender gap in AI, with male users accounting for approximately 65%. Behind these two seemingly contradictory conclusions are different research methods and data sources. The NBER report is based on first-party platform data, which can accurately track the dynamic changes in user groups (the gender composition of new users). Other studies, however, are mostly based on third-party traffic analysis or surveys, which may have biases, and their results more often reflect the historical stock of male users. The NBER data depicts a dynamic trend, where the popularization of AI is gradually correcting the early gender imbalance through the addition of new users. This process is overcoming socio-cultural barriers such as lower awareness of AI tools among women, lack of confidence, and moral concerns about â€œcheating.â€

Part Four: Scrutiny of Methodology: Beyond the Data Itself

Section titled â€œPart Four: Scrutiny of Methodology: Beyond the Data Itselfâ€

4.1 Innovations and Advantages of the NBER Reportâ€™s Methodology

Section titled â€œ4.1 Innovations and Advantages of the NBER Reportâ€™s Methodologyâ€

The NBER reportâ€™s prominence lies not only in its data conclusions but also in its unique and innovative research methodology. The report pioneered the use of â€œPrivacy-Preserving Automated Classificationâ€ and â€œData Clean Room (DCR)â€ protocols.

This method addresses the core contradiction in previous research between â€œprivacy protectionâ€ and â€œlarge-scale, fine-grained data analysis.â€ The report uses large language models (LLMs) rather than human labor to classify anonymous and de-identified conversational content, ensuring that human researchers never see user message content from start to finish. When analyzing sensitive data such as occupation and education, the research team adopted strict DCR protocols, further safeguarding user privacy by restricting query results (e.g., groups must exceed 100 users). This methodological innovation sets a new industry standard for future AI behavior research, achieving the goal of obtaining large-scale behavioral data without sacrificing user privacy.

4.2 Limitations and Potential Challenges

Section titled â€œ4.2 Limitations and Potential Challengesâ€

Despite its groundbreaking nature, the NBER reportâ€™s analysis also has inherent limitations. The report explicitly states that its analysis sample is limited to ChatGPTâ€™s consumer plans (Free, Plus, Pro) and does not include enterprise-level applications (Business, Enterprise) or API usage.

This limitation is crucial because it means the picture painted by the report represents only the â€œtip of the icebergâ€ of AIâ€™s impact. Enterprise users and consumers have fundamental differences in motivations, needs, and use cases. Enterprises are more concerned with high-value use cases such as â€œautomation,â€ â€œdata security,â€ and â€œcustomization.â€ Compared to the â€œcognitive co-pilotâ€ mode dominated by â€œpractical guidanceâ€ and â€œinformation seekingâ€ in the consumer version, enterprise AI (such as ChatGPT Enterprise or Claude API) is more often used for direct â€œautomationâ€ tasks like code generation, document summarization, and customer service automation. Therefore, the consumer behavior map depicted in the NBER report cannot fully reflect AIâ€™s multiple roles in the entire economic system.

Summary and Outlook: Trends, Challenges, and Future Insights

Section titled â€œSummary and Outlook: Trends, Challenges, and Future Insightsâ€

5.1 Summary of Core Arguments of the Report

Section titled â€œ5.1 Summary of Core Arguments of the Reportâ€
  • The adoption rate of AI is unprecedented, and its value is shifting from workplace productivity to broader personal life efficiency and consumer surplus.
  • The core value of AI on the user side is not to â€œreplace humans,â€ but to act as a â€œcognitive co-pilotâ€ to help humans make decisions and solve problems through â€œpractical guidanceâ€ and â€œinformation seeking.â€
  • Media narratives about AI use cases (e.g., programming, emotional companionship) and user groups (e.g., gender gap) show significant discrepancies with facts revealed by large-scale data, reflecting the complex reality of platform differentiation and public cognitive lag.
  • AI research methodologies are progressing, but existing research still has inherent limitations, particularly in its inability to fully reflect the fundamental differences between consumer and enterprise AI use cases.

5.2 Reflections on the Future

Section titled â€œ5.2 Reflections on the Futureâ€
  • Impact on the Economy: AIâ€™s â€œcognitive co-pilotâ€ model will reshape knowledge-intensive work. Its core value will be to enhance human judgment, not to replace labor. This will create new demands for human soft skills such as â€œcritical thinkingâ€ and â€œquestioning ability.â€
  • Impact on Society: As AI becomes more widespread among low-income countries and women, it is expected to become a new tool for narrowing the digital divide and gender gap. However, potential biases and data privacy risks still need to be guarded against.
  • Outlook for the Future: Trends indicate that we are moving from an era where AI is â€œtechnologyâ€ to an era where AI is a â€œlifestyle.â€ In the future, AI will not only be a tool for improving work efficiency but also an indispensable part of personal growth, life management, and decision support. We must understand and adapt to this transformation with a critical and dynamic perspective, rather than being misled by static figures and one-sided narratives. The future of AI will be co-written by how humans collaborate and live with it.

item.title: Engineer Growth Principles in the AI Era
item.content:encoded:
This article distills four often-overlooked yet crucial growth principles: argue less about whoâ€™s right and more for winâ€“wins, ship first then optimize, donâ€™t fear overlapâ€”insist on differentiation, and stop wasting time proving yourself.

Introduction

Section titled â€œIntroductionâ€

As AI advances at breakneck speed, engineers face not only a technical upgrade but also a test of worldview and workplace mindset. Have you ever alienated a colleague by clinging to â€œbeing rightâ€? Missed a window chasing perfection? These are common, and exactly what this piece explores. After years of trial and error, Iâ€™ve refined four practical growth principles that continue to work in the real world. I hope they resonate.

1. Incentive Thinking: Donâ€™t Argue Right vs. Wrongâ€”Argue for Winâ€“Win

Section titled â€œ1. Incentive Thinking: Donâ€™t Argue Right vs. Wrongâ€”Argue for Winâ€“Winâ€

Early in my career, I was eager to prove I was â€œright.â€ Over time I realized: in organizations, â€œrightâ€ is rarely the most important thingâ€”â€œwhat benefits the project/teamâ€ is. Obsessing over abstract â€œeleganceâ€ and â€œpure logicâ€ while ignoring delivery, risk, resources, and ROI balance easily gets labeled as nitpicking.

Key mindset shifts:

  • From â€œI must winâ€ to â€œDoes the team get better overall?â€
  • From â€œtheoretical perfectionâ€ to â€œmaximizing this iterationâ€™s valueâ€
  • From â€œdebate positionsâ€ to â€œcollaborative game â†’ winâ€“win optionsâ€

A practical trick: before speaking or rebutting, silently count to 5 and ask yourself:

  1. Will this statement move the decision or outcome forward?
  2. Is it fair and beneficial to both the other party and the team?
  3. Is there a way to express this with lower conflict cost?

Argue less about right/wrong, aim for winâ€“wins, and your reputation as a collaboratorâ€”along with your influence and trustâ€”will rise naturally.

2. No Premature Optimization: Ship First, Optimize After Validation

Section titled â€œ2. No Premature Optimization: Ship First, Optimize After Validationâ€

Perfectionism often delays the first version. When users havenâ€™t validated and value isnâ€™t closed-loop, pouring effort into performance, abstraction, and grand architecture is classic â€œpremature optimization.â€

The first version (V0 / MVP) has only two missions:

  • Validate there are real users who want it.
  • Validate the path is worth doubling down on.

Practice tips:

  • Set your â€œMinimal Success Levelâ€ (MSL) for this round.
  • Cap initial delivery investment (person-days / complexity / dependencies).
  • Leave room for refactoring instead of hard-locking the architecture up-front.
  • Track hypothesis â†’ ship â†’ feedback â†’ iteration cadence (accelerate loops, donâ€™t just pile features).

When you see stable core usage + 100+ real, recurring users + paying signals or strong retention, thatâ€™s when systematic refactors/perf work actually pay off.

The mantra isnâ€™t â€œsettle for less,â€ itâ€™s â€œvalidate fast + optimize with purpose.â€

3. Donâ€™t Be Intimidated by Logic: Itâ€™s Fine If Others Did Itâ€”Build Your Difference

Section titled â€œ3. Donâ€™t Be Intimidated by Logic: Itâ€™s Fine If Others Did Itâ€”Build Your Differenceâ€

â€œSomeoneâ€™s done itâ€ isnâ€™t a veto; itâ€™s market proof and a learning sample. Differentiation isnâ€™t only technicalâ€”often it comes from:

  • Perspective: a new framing, entry point, or audience focus for the same problem
  • Experience: compressed flows, friction removal, instant feedback
  • Value exchange: open/closed source, subscription/one-off, tool + community hybrids
  • Narrative and persona: trust and cultural tone as invisible moats

Suggested execution steps:

  1. List a pros/cons matrix of existing solutions.
  2. Highlight under-served user scenarios and emotional pain points.
  3. Define your â€œDifferentiated Coreâ€ via subtraction: the smallest set that makes you distinct.
  4. Build a demo with perceivable differences first; collect real feedback, then expand.

Donâ€™t overestimate the risk of â€œrepetitionâ€ and underestimate the compounding of â€œconsistency + differentiation + focus.â€

4. Stop Proving Yourself: Spend Energy on Building and Joy

Section titled â€œ4. Stop Proving Yourself: Spend Energy on Building and Joyâ€

For technologists, the scarcest resource isnâ€™t toolsâ€”itâ€™s sustained, deep attention. Instead of bleeding energy in pointless debates and emotional tug-of-war, convert your will to win into building power.

Common self-draining traps:

  • â€œI must make them admit I know more.â€
  • â€œTheir lack of recognition = Iâ€™m not good.â€
  • â€œI must clap back at every jab.â€

Replacements:

  • Let outcomes/code/metrics/demos speak.
  • Identify â€œnon-productive debatesâ€: not falsifiable + no decision rights + emotion-led.
  • Maintain a personal â€œattention blacklistâ€: donâ€™t trigger, donâ€™t chase, donâ€™t loop.
  • Build positive loops: output (articles/open source/prototypes) â†’ feedback â†’ improvement.

Let your work establish your identity and reputationâ€”not momentary keyboard wins.

Final Thoughts

Section titled â€œFinal Thoughtsâ€

To recap the four principles:

  1. Argue less about right/wrong; aim for winâ€“wins.
  2. Validate value first; then refine and optimize.
  3. Donâ€™t fear overlap; insist on differentiation.
  4. Donâ€™t waste energy proving; commit to sustained creation.

In the AI era, tool dividends are accelerating â€œcapability depreciation.â€ Knowing a stack is no longer a lasting moat. What compounds sustainably is:

  • Mindset flexibility
  • Strategic execution
  • Differentiated expression
  • Focus and continuous retrospection

The path of growth is inevitably winding. If your direction is right, the distance wonâ€™t matter. May we embrace the technological tide while consolidating inner judgment and creativity.
